As a Factorio:SA/DSP/Satisfactory-player, I must say, I really like the simplified "factory building" in the game. Perhaps it might put off other more hardcore factory-affectionados, but I don't believe having more complex factory chains would work so well with the intense combat in the game, at least not without a ton more of QoL functions. But that's mostly not needed, I feel like the game has struck a pretty perfect balance.

The mid
I like the weapon modding system alright, but it feels like it's was more or less an afterthought, especially how 'jankily' it's implemented in the menus. I feel like it could be a little more fun if you could even mod the starting rarity weapons a little. It feels a little weird that you get white rarity mods(that are pretty garbage to being with), but you can't use them in any white rarity weapons until you first blue rarity drops, and there you can only add ONE garbage quality mod to it... that does no impact at all, so why bother? I'd instead like to see 2 slots on common weapons to begin with(the mods that drop at the same time are, like mentioned, still garbage, so with 2 slots, they won't do much, but at least something), then 3, 4 and 5 slots on the following rarities. Sure, probably not gonna happen, since it will take a pretty thorough remake of the inventory GUI and some serious rebalancing of the mods and weapons themselves. For example, I'm running around with a workshop-mod that allows me to have 16 mech-modules slots(instead of the original 4 slots) in my current game, it's really fun, but utterly game-breaking, I'm basically untouchable even if most of the modules are only Purple and Blue rarity with only a few Red ones.
Even if the factory process chains are rather simple, I still miss some quality of life stuff from the real fatory builders. I still would like to have the ability to just copy a setup I've already made and paste it down somewhere else(not blueprinting, just copy). Like farming setups, liquid processing setups or small temporary turret-setups tuned to the biomes enemies I could put down if I need to quickly expand between the waves, stuff that gets built lots and lots of times and are always the same. Or if I just want to reposition a setup, copying instead of rebuilding the whole damn setup again would help tremendously! The build menus are fine for basic stuff, but are rather limited and cumbersome to work with for larger builds, so this would would make the large strides you have to take to enter the late-game feel like less of a chore and more fun... IMHO.

The Bad
Can't think of something REALLY bad, perhaps inventory GUI is a bit needlesly convoluted and the research trees could do with some more clarifications. Not a fan of the tech trees having unknown techs, especially in a mostly linear tech tree, especially since I've completed the game once, and especially since most of them don't specify how I acquire them. Sure, I'm guessing many of them are from the DLC's, but if I don't have the DLC and you don't specify(advertise) that they are from the DLC, then WHY have them there at all??? Just let me see all the tech and ALL requirements for unlocking them(if any(be it scanning a certain tree or buying a certain DLC)), at least after completing the campaign once. The tech trees are so huge, and there's three of them, so I find myself constantly looking for a specific tech I want and knew I had in my last run, only to never find it, having to resort to looking through wikis and reddit threads.

Until the endgame update and the mega structures, this was great. It had many options and ways you could tackle the game. You could do the DLC in any order if you're far enough, you could progress the story regardless of your skills, and get the full experience.

With the mega structures, the focus has become singular - do the DLC to get the nukes, obliterate everything. There is no more, "We must save the world and us, too." There is no more balance - it is literally, "Waste all of the resources on this mega structure and kill everything that comes to destroy it."

The mega structures take colossal amounts of resources to maintain and build. That's understandable since that's literally all they're meant for. Sure, they have some good benefits, like showing the entire map and its mining spots, or increasing farm yield, but... they're thankless and full of bugs.

Get this. I built the entire thing up and powered the final structure. Mr. Riggs told me, "Hey, the last wave is coming, better be ready." I was like like, well, ok, good, bring it on. I had good defenses, I had good items and gear, so start it up. What happened next was just pathetic.

My entire base was obliterated. My mega structures, which you can build more of on one map because nothing stops you, well, one bit the dust. More than half of my base, despite finishing all of the DLC and having upgrades everywhere, was just wiped out because multiple mega units came out and just killed everything. The mods these things have are stupid - heal all in an area, prevent damage to it unless you're in its bubble, and so forth. How is a tower supposed to kill that? This isn't that kind of game!

The worst thing is you can't repair your dead mega structures, you have to just dismantle it and start from zero. I had all of them maxed. I had all of their research maxed - I literally cannot research anything else in this game and have to start over mining titanium and uranium because of these monstrosities.
The entire tone is off here, you're not solving anything and are instead killing literally all life with nukes to build stupid structures to strip-mine the planet. I can no longer maintain titanium because all of the cooling needed for these things, like what is that? The power plants alone rip apart an entire mining outpost!

Ok, so whatever. I build it back up and try again, thinking, "I have the power, I have the cooling, I have the magma and whatever else it needs. Turn it on - I died once, the final wave won't come again. That'd be dumb." The final wave comes again and just rips it all apart again. I built it all up a second time, it gets utterly annihilated again. I revert to my save and can't build my arcology again because I can't repair my dead structures.

What a cycle of hate toward the player. You make it unwinnable, you make the structures unfixable, you make the economy function on death and strip mines, and you make it endless. Every time you power the final building, the death wave comes and literally kills some feeble part of your base, restarting the cycle. At that point, one of your outposts is out of resources, so you're now forced to spend hours building another to try again.

What happened here? Why do I have to fight monsters with affixes like in an ARPG with just bullet sponges and healing all over the place, not to mention invicibility zones? Why does my base mean nothing? Why is research thrown away in favor of just killing everything? Why do the resource outposts just get spat on by the requirements of endgame buildings? Are you serious with this game, because I don't get it anymore. You had something special and now have this mess where you have you spam special attacks, your towers just die all the time, you waste our lives with buildings that can't be repaired, and you're merciless in failure. Are you happy?

Get this. I built the entire thing up and powered the final structure. Mr. Riggs told me, "Hey, the last wave is coming, better be ready." I was like like, well, ok, good, bring it on. I had good defenses, I had good items and gear, so start it up. What happened next was just pathetic.

My entire base was obliterated. My mega structures, which you can build more of on one map because nothing stops you, well, one bit the dust. More than half of my base, despite finishing all of the DLC and having upgrades everywhere, was just wiped out because multiple mega units came out and just killed everything. The mods these things have are stupid - heal all in an area, prevent damage to it unless you're in its bubble, and so forth. How is a tower supposed to kill that? This isn't that kind of game!

The worst thing is you can't repair your dead mega structures, you have to just dismantle it and start from zero. I had all of them maxed. I had all of their research maxed - I literally cannot research anything else in this game and have to start over mining titanium and uranium because of these monstrosities.
The entire tone is off here, you're not solving anything and are instead killing literally all life with nukes to build stupid structures to strip-mine the planet. I can no longer maintain titanium because all of the cooling needed for these things, like what is that? The power plants alone rip apart an entire mining outpost!

Ok, so whatever. I build it back up and try again, thinking, "I have the power, I have the cooling, I have the magma and whatever else it needs. Turn it on - I died once, the final wave won't come again. That'd be dumb." The final wave comes again and just rips it all apart again. I built it all up a second time, it gets utterly annihilated again. I revert to my save and can't build my arcology again because I can't repair my dead structures.

What a cycle of hate toward the player. You make it unwinnable, you make the structures unfixable, you make the economy function on death and strip mines, and you make it endless. Every time you power the final building, the death wave comes and literally kills some feeble part of your base, restarting the cycle. At that point, one of your outposts is out of resources, so you're now forced to spend hours building another to try again.

What happened here? Why do I have to fight monsters with affixes like in an ARPG with just bullet sponges and healing all over the place, not to mention invicibility zones? Why does my base mean nothing? Why is research thrown away in favor of just killing everything? Why do the resource outposts just get spat on by the requirements of endgame buildings? Are you serious with this game, because I don't get it anymore. You had something special and now have this mess where you have you spam special attacks, your towers just die all the time, you waste our lives with buildings that can't be repaired, and you're merciless in failure. Are you happy?

Putting a negative review on this game is kinda heartbreaking. For a long time this was one of the easiest recommendations I've been making to people. Reading the dev log for the latest update that reworks movement skills (around mid October 2025) has been depressing, and a clear indication the game is going in a direction that I don't enjoy.

There are big issues and small issues. Some of the biggest issues have been how the economy was reworked. As the amount of bases you can have has increased, the amount of resources you can be harvesting at once has increased. To compensate, all researches now have a huge resource cost associated with them. Even the first ones you can do. You might be sitting afk for 10+mins waiting for resources because you don't get lots of resources outposts until the late game. Why this massive roadblock exists early is bizare and fun killing.
Tier 2 and 3 resource extractors now harvest half the amount. These changes mean that you need a higher amount of resource outposts simply to get to the level we had before. Why increase the amount of bases we can have when there is no benefit to it, and the huge downside of butchering the early game and wasting our time with setting up all these extra bases?

The resource cost to researches has other side effects. A lot of researches that unlock things that need rarer or later game resources also need said resource to research. This may not sound like an issue, after all if you don't have the resource you can't use the results of the research. However some items that require resources X are gated by researches that unlock items that use resource Y. Before you could research the item you can't use to get the item you can use. Now you can't. This forces a much more linear and fixed path through the game, rather than the more open choices we had before. You can turn down resource costs to 1% but not 0%, you can't get this choice back.

Previously, weapons and gear you crafted had some degree of randomness to them. The higher tier the weapon/item, the more random bonuses it would have. I can understand why some players would find making 20 of a weapon, choosing the best, and then dismantling the other 18 or 19 to be boring. Personally I found it a nice addition that let me have a little more choice in what I wanted from my gear. Do I want something super ammo efficient? Then build a weapon with better efficiency and throw on some ammo cost reduction mods. Weapons with different stats still exist, but they have to be gathered either from 'anomalies' in the environment, or as random drops from enemies. This is a pure downgrade, as we are now massively timegated in trying to aquire the gear we want. While the game does have some ARPG elements to the how combat works, it's not an ARPG and was never trying to be one. I don't want an ARPG. Stop moving the game into a new genre I beg.

The movement skill reworks have gone in this direction to. Rather than simple functional movement skills, they've all becoming flashy damaging abilities like in an ARPG. The teleport skill, one of my 2 most core movement skills, has been made visually and functionally frustrating going by the gifs they've shown off/the devs descriptions of how it works now.

Then there are the smaller issues, mainly visual. With coop being a new focus, the devs have decided to reduce a lot of visuals to make things more 'readable'. This makes the game less visually interesting and dynamic. Smaller, shorter lived explosions. Effects removed. All in the service of a mode I'm not even playing.

There is *one* half good thing in this update. The devs have let us keep the original version of the game via a beta branch. Unfortunately that means no more updates, being locked out of the expanded late game (might have been good? I don't know, can't stomach the early game anymore so I'll never get to play it), and the further expansions. I don't have enough time to spend modding the game's visuals back to pre-nerf, removing the resource costs, restoring the economy, etc. I won't play the old version anymore since this has left such a bad taste, and I'll be lamenting missing out on potentially good new content buried deep in the botched rework of a game that was previously amazing and never needed it.

[h1]Feels like an endless tutorial[/h1]
I might have gotten the wrong impression, but I envisioned The Riftbreaker as Factorio but with an emphasis on combat and exploration. On a surface level that assumption was accurate, but in practice the two halves of the game did not mesh. 

The combat and exploration part is passable enough. Combat looks and feels great, but most of it just amounts to gunning down massive hordes of creatures. Except for a few tougher enemies, it was more about being at the right place at the right time and conserving ammo. Defending you base is a bit odd since it grows quite large and you cannot possible use turrets to defend yourself from the big hordes. Unlike Factorio, where you can predict which direction enemies are going to attack from, as well as being able to wall of big sections of the map, in The Riftbreaker enemies attack from random locations, the terrain is too open to section off and turrets are too limited to make static defenses viable. You are better off just teleporting to where enemies are attacking and shoot them yourself. Outside of attack waves, the enemies never pose any threat and do not attack your base, so it is a bit of all or nothing.

The base building was promising at first. Gather resources to build new buildings and upgrade your factory as well as forging new equipment. But it quickly plateaus and never increases in complexity. There is no logistics management and only a few multi-stage recipes. Most of your expansion is just building more and more of the same buildings.

When the game started to lose me entirely is when I realized that the game just followed the same loop over and over. Explore a new area, find new resources, unlock the next tier of stuff and return to your base. In essence it is what every survival crafting game should be about, but it was so repetitive and it felt copy pasted. Progression is also mostly linear with set objectives to complete in a set order. It kept waiting for the tutorial to be over so I could explore the game freely, but it never happened. So sense of freedom or problem solving, just follow orders.

Riftbreaker is one of those games I wish I could put like a little middling thumb on. I think it's... fine, for about half of it, and then the other half just becomes a bit of a chore. It goes from "Oh, this is novel!" to "The Keywords for today are: Repetitive, tedious."

A lot of this game is... straightforward, or simple? And I don't think that's a bad thing, it was probably the right choice for this game, I can't help that it also makes the game feel a bit mindless. There isn't really that much complexity to the building, nor the defending, nor the combat really. Sometimes it's fun to hold the mouse buttons and watch hordes of creatures turn into groups of red mists, othertimes it's really dull. There's an initial satisfaction to watching a tower-line hold a group of enemies all on its own, but then it... Now I'm repeating myself.
That is a *lot* of this game. Busy work and chores. I don't dislike it enough to give it a hard no, but I also don't like it enough to give it a hard yes.

This is only made worse when you're exploring other areas. The flow is like this:
Deploy to an area -> oh no there's something we didn't see that complicates things -> we should research a solution to this -> go to new place -> Oh there's new materials here -> hunt around for ages gathering small amounts of this resource -> get enough to scan for big deposit -> also there's some optional material (but go get it because you need new guns) -> setup two entirely new bases and then half ass them because if you aren't here you don't need to defend it.

Except it gets more irritating each time? I don't think it's bad in isolation, but these issues are rarely complex enough to have to dedicate entire... chunks of gameplay around it. The Acid area has fungus that rapidly grows all over the map. So now you get to spend ages running around the corners of the map isolating the fungus colonies with flooring that doesn't stop them from growing sometimes, or you just blow up the acid colonies because despite all of Ashley's cautioning of "This could have negative effects on the ecosystem", there apparently isn't any.

Or the lava area. You can't build anywhere that's outside of cold areas. THis is initially interesting, since you're forced to build outposts around the cold plants that naturally spring up around this zone. And also there's big magnetic rocks that stop you from building near them - I hope you went to the acid zone first to get the acid gun that destroys them, not that you'd know without constant sustained fire with a dialogue that "sort of" hints at this.
And that's skipping the part where you go here, find the complication, go to a new area to research a solution, go to a new area to get material samples, go to a new area to actually get the materials, etc.
And when you're done with all of that, you go back to HQ and build your big portal back to home and then defend it for a few minutes against huge attack waves that are a problem if you haven't prepared properly (get some long range artillery in there and a few shield generators at your frontlines), and... wait for 2 minutes because the attack waves stopped and the portal is halfway done. Huh.
That's like, basically the whole game. Do a thing, have ashley and riggs back and forth about things they both know but you're being tutorialised. Go to a new place. Dont do anything at new place but scan (thank god for scanner turrets). Go to new place. Find thing. Research thing. Unlock the solution. Build a real base at the new place. Half ass it because you're tired of defending everything. Repeat several times. Now win the game.

The game seems to just have everything in it, to the point that the games focus is sacrificed. Ostensibly, the game should be a medium-fast paced base-building w/ tower defense + exploration experience, but somehow manages to be a slow-paced twin-stick looter-shooter. It feels as if the latter cannibalized the former.

Everything feels like a massive chore.

#1 The bioscanner, it takes 3-4 seconds per scan but you'll need 30+ scans of a creature to learn what damage type it's weak to. So you are subject to this incredibly boring mechanic unless you google the information instead.

#2 The research, it takes forever, you can't just build more labs b/c there's a maximum number you are allowed to build. Research also costs a mountain of resources for some reason, meaning the typical experience is to dump the majority of your resources into *just starting the research process*, then wait around doing nothing b/c you are out of resources for the next 5 minutes. Or you might try...

#3 Exploring, there is another pod of enemies every 5 feet so just walking around looking for stuff is like trudging through deep mud, it's so obnoxious that the best upgrade for your mech is stealth. And you will want stealth for...

#4 The geoscanner, slightly more tolerable than the bioscanner, a ton of resource patches are hidden so get used to holding space-bar everywhere you go.

#5 No blueprints, practically a mortal sin for a game like this.

#6 The loot. Jesus Christ what is with the loot. You could probably finish this game without ever crafting a weapon b/c the wildlife on this unexplored alien planet are constantly dropping miniguns and rocket launchers; Mech cosmetics, different color floors & lamps, statues, weapon attachments, you name it and some space-raptor you disintegrated has it in their pocket. From what I've experienced the exploration objects ("bioanomalies") hold maybe 1 - 2 loot items and you need to explore (see above) to find them, but a typical attack wave will drop a dozen or so loot items so why even bother.

#7 Charge-Mode on weapons. The combat in this game consists of *several thousand* enemies rushing at you very fast, so why, why, why does *almost every weapon* have a charge-mode. Charge-mode (holding the button down), forces the player to split their concentration between the tsunami of space-raptors chasing them and watching/listening to the mechs right arm for the correct time to release the right mouse button; additionally charge-mode slows the mech down thus eliminating the ability to kite opponents. These are design decisions which strongly conflict. Aside from some charge-modes just being downright silly (you can charge the nuke launcher to make it nuke harder), most offer little to no advantage at all. But let us be real, you're only going to use about 10% of the arsenal anyway, none of them with charge-mode, minigun/plasmagun/laser/boxing-gloves/chainsaws.

Very clunky and unpolished. Even in "version 2.0", four years after its original release, it feels like an early beta. The elevator pitch for the game is that it wants to synergize several different genres by feeding rewards from doing well in one area into doing well in other areas. It's a neat idea, and it's executed well enough that I did play one whole campaign, but the execution is so messy that I would not recommend it for single player and probably not for multiplayer.

For me, the nail in the coffin of this recommendation is that the balance between different game aspects is bad. There is one right way to play in terms of power scaling and it makes all the other ways minor fiddly obstacles. In single player this is annoying, and I imagine that in multiplayer it would just be sad that the people who focus on different aspects see far less award for their efforts.

There is a very simple exponential loop in base building resource generation that shows up a few hours in and stays for the rest of the game. It removes most of the challenge and most incentive to engage with all the other mechanics. Base building stops being a puzzle and just becomes a matter of manually printing a template. Enemies die to "just use more gun". Even narratively this option is the "green" one. Tech is cheap compared to the power potential of base building.

Equipment handling is a nightmare. Maybe that's subjective, but the reward for doing it well is objectively pitiful. While base building gives you orders of magnitude improvement, equipment bonuses are less than +50% even at the highest level of equipment slot. Your equipment dps improves by one (1) order of magnitude over the course of the game, but the majority of that is locked behind technologies that take resources from base building.

Combat is serviceable but doesn't really evolve over the course of the game. In the endgame, it starts lagging even in singleplayer, with over a second of input lag and a much reduced game speed even though Steam reports a 100fps framerate. Every weapon exists at every tech level, all the enemies that matter just become tougher reskins rather than requiring a different approach, and boss enemies are too weak to reward planning. Bioscanning adds some extra challenge but its rewards are miniscule and become logarithmically more miniscule (did you like that +5% for scanning a hundred enemies instead of shooting them? How about +10% for scanning a thousand?), and there is no complexity to it.

Exploration is fine but seems underdeveloped. There are three biomes and you only need four bases, though each of the other three bases has a short fetch quest sequence where some missions actually require creative puzzle solving. Strangely, despite the game giving you multiple different options and despite the tech tree having resource requirements that incentivize you to prioritize specific biomes depending on your basebuilding and/or weapon choice, the explanation of mechanics expects one specific order (top to bottom in the hub menu). Doing it "out of order" means hearing voice lines that refer to events that haven't happened yet and lacking information about how to use unintuitive UI elements.

The story is bare-bones, but from the amount of voice lines you wouldn't think so. They even have the characters lampshade how perfunctory their voicelines are. The characters are one-dimensional and there is no character development to speak of, and the first time the pilot's supposed care for the environment actually translates into a mechanical choice is choosing whether to go for the True Ending or not. The plot up to this point is just "do the work necessary to open a rift gate back to earth", with not even a hint of any other option until you're one keypress away from opening the gate.

Audio design is subpar. There is no volume limiter for multiple entities producing the same noise so upgrading a field of solar panels blows out your speakers. The pilot's voice actor doesn't seem to have been given good direction for her lines: her tone of voice and use of emphasis don't correlate with the gameplay and story implications of what she's saying.

The graphics design is inoffensive. Customization is perfunctory. There are at most 10 texture-only skins for your character, and a few buildings that do nothing and cost a small amount of resources.

Performance-wise, the game is poorly optimized, even within the confines of the engine. As mentioned above, endgame combat lags even on a ‚Ç¨1000 PC, but even just the bases necessary for the first ending seemed to cause a bit of lag despite only one base being visible at a time. And while mines do run out while you're not looking, enemies do not spawn, so there's no gameplay justification for rendering other bases in enough detail to cause lag. One enemy (the yeast) expands on its own and starts lagging the game if it is left unchecked for 15 minutes, despite just being a stationary field that is safe to ignore from a game mechanics perspective. There is no engine reason for this enemy to take this many resources to render, it's just less programming.

If this game was in early beta, I would say that it's brimming with potential. Tweak the game balance and performance, do a second pass on the voice lines, and it would honestly be great. But given it's four years after release, with a bunch of DLCs and with 2,0 adding more features rather than polishing the existing ones, I do not recommend this game.

I decided to buy Riftbreaker because I enjoyed playing Co-op survival - it was really challenging mode and had tons of fun on the playtest, why not buy it and enjoy the campaign?

The game is less of a Factorio/factory builder but a more complex Supreme Commander with buildings-only instead of units. I had a few 'invisible unplaceable zones' that were apparently managed by a nearby loot crystal summoning enemies - NOT the crystal itself but apparently the spawn zone of one group prevented me placing objects there. OK. 

VOICE ACTING & WRITING
Honestly the less story writing there is, the better. The premise is pretty good, ultimately ruined by pro-bug activist that has bleeding heart for the local environment that would maul anyone within seconds. One thing that factory building games should avoid is making cringy voice-acting, limiting it just to prompts - Factorio does this masterfully, Satisfactory does it good as it only does per-research basis.  
This game doesn't know this and it will play dialogue at every step - not enough resources, bad placement, attack incoming, storyline blabbering and so on. The mech AI is OK and I can stomach him, however the main Mary Sue is unbearable to listen to. No, I don't care about bugs, I don't care to hear how you lost your arm for 100th time that we never see anyway. Mr Riggs rightfully calls MC insane and I wish AI would court-martial her in the field by just throwing her out of the suit and leaving to live with the bugs if her bleeding heart loves them so much.

UPDATE TWO-POINT-POO
Terrible waiting times for 'end game content' - even with max labs (which are limited), you can do ONLY THREE RESEARCHES PER HOUR, AND THERE ARE 20 NEEDED! Making long research makes sense IF there is a way to make it faster. Factorio allows you to build more research labs and supply to accelerate it as much as you wish, and Satisfactory allows you to do the same with Space Elevator progress (but just industry). Yes, you CAN upgrade labs but with limited quantity and 'end-game' you will already have those maxed. This either feels like a bad joke or a malicious move to make Players 'enjoy more content with 2.0' which is clearly seen with insane growth of resource cost and research length. More time spent does not mean its better.

__
To be honest, Survival is more fun than Campaign itself, especially if you do it with your friends. But if you want to commit to a campaign, play Factorio, Satisfactory or another factory builder game that respects your time and doesn't beat your head with environmentalism. If you adjust research sliders to 10%, turn off dialogue volume I think you will enjoy the game if its on the sale.

Until the endgame update and the mega structures, this was great. It had many options and ways you could tackle the game. You could do the DLC in any order if you're far enough, you could progress the story regardless of your skills, and get the full experience.

There is no more balance - it is literally, "Waste all of the resources on this mega structure and kill everything that comes to destroy it."

The mega structures take colossal amounts of resources to maintain and build. That's understandable since that's literally all they're meant for. Sure, they have some good benefits, like showing the entire map and its mining spots, or increasing farm yield, but... they're thankless and full of bugs.

Get this. I built the entire thing up and powered the final structure. Mr. Riggs told me, "Hey, the last wave is coming, better be ready." I was like like, well, ok, good, bring it on. I had good defenses, I had good items and gear, so start it up. What happened next was just pathetic.

My entire base was obliterated. My mega structures, which you can build more of on one map because nothing stops you, well, one bit the dust. More than half of my base, despite finishing all of the DLC and having upgrades everywhere, was just wiped out because multiple mega units came out and just killed everything. The mods these things have are stupid - heal all in an area, prevent damage to it unless you're in its bubble, and so forth. How is a tower supposed to kill that? This isn't that kind of game!

The worst thing is you can't repair your dead mega structures, you have to just dismantle it and start from zero. I had all of them maxed. I had all of their research maxed - I literally cannot research anything else in this game and have to start over mining titanium and uranium because of these monstrosities.
The entire tone is off here, you're not solving anything and are instead killing literally all life with nukes to build stupid structures to strip-mine the planet. I can no longer maintain titanium because all of the cooling needed for these things, like what is that? The power plants alone rip apart an entire mining outpost!

Ok, so whatever. I build it back up and try again, thinking, "I have the power, I have the cooling, I have the magma and whatever else it needs. Turn it on - I died once, the final wave won't come again. That'd be dumb." The final wave comes again and just rips it all apart again. I built it all up a second time, it gets utterly annihilated again. I revert to my save and can't build my arcology again because I can't repair my dead structures.

What a cycle of hate toward the player. You make it unwinnable, you make the structures unfixable, you make the economy function on death and strip mines, and you make it endless. Every time you power the final building, the death wave comes and literally kills some feeble part of your base, restarting the cycle. At that point, one of your outposts is out of resources, so you're now forced to spend hours building another to try again.

What happened here? Why do I have to fight monsters with affixes like in an ARPG with just bullet sponges and healing all over the place, not to mention invicibility zones? Why does my base mean nothing? Why is research thrown away in favor of just killing everything? Why do the resource outposts just get spat on by the requirements of endgame buildings? Are you serious with this game, because I don't get it anymore. You had something special and now have this mess where you have you spam special attacks, your towers just die all the time, you waste our lives with buildings that can't be repaired, and you're merciless in failure. Are you happy?

Putting a negative review on this game is kinda heartbreaking. For a long time this was one of the easiest recommendations I've been making to people. Hands down one of my favourite games of all time. I even did some speed running. However the coop updates have pretty much ruined the game imo. I played maybe 20 minutes into a new game once the update was out and haven't touched it since. Reading the dev log for the latest update that reworks movement skills (around mid October 2025) has been depressing, and a clear indication the game is going in a direction that I don't enjoy.

There are big issues and small issues. Some of the biggest issues have been how the economy was reworked. As the amount of bases you can have has increased, the amount of resources you can be harvesting at once has increased. To compensate, all researches now have a huge resource cost associated with them. Even the first ones you can do. You might be sitting afk for 10+mins waiting for resources because you don't get lots of resources outposts until the late game. Why this massive roadblock exists early is bizare and fun killing.
Tier 2 and 3 resource extractors now harvest half the amount. These changes mean that you need a higher amount of resource outposts simply to get to the level we had before. Why increase the amount of bases we can have when there is no benefit to it, and the huge downside of butchering the early game and wasting our time with setting up all these extra bases?

The resource cost to researches has other side effects. A lot of researches that unlock things that need rarer or later game resources also need said resource to research. This may not sound like an issue, after all if you don't have the resource you can't use the results of the research. However some items that require resources X are gated by researches that unlock items that use resource Y. Before you could research the item you can't use to get the item you can use. Now you can't. This forces a much more linear and fixed path through the game, rather than the more open choices we had before. You can turn down resource costs to 1% but not 0%, you can't get this choice back.

Previously, weapons and gear you crafted had some degree of randomness to them. The higher tier the weapon/item, the more random bonuses it would have. I can understand why some players would find making 20 of a weapon, choosing the best, and then dismantling the other 18 or 19 to be boring. Personally I found it a nice addition that let me have a little more choice in what I wanted from my gear. Do I want something super ammo efficient? Then build a weapon with better efficiency and throw on some ammo cost reduction mods. Weapons with different stats still exist, but they have to be gathered either from 'anomalies' in the environment, or as random drops from enemies. This is a pure downgrade, as we are now massively timegated in trying to aquire the gear we want. While the game does have some ARPG elements to the how combat works, it's not an ARPG and was never trying to be one. I don't want an ARPG. Stop moving the game into a new genre I beg.

The movement skill reworks have gone in this direction to. Rather than simple functional movement skills, they've all becoming flashy damaging abilities like in an ARPG. The teleport skill, one of my 2 most core movement skills, has been made visually and functionally frustrating going by the gifs they've shown off/the devs descriptions of how it works now.

Then there are the smaller issues, mainly visual. With coop being a new focus, the devs have decided to reduce a lot of visuals to make things more 'readable'. This makes the game less visually interesting and dynamic. Smaller, shorter lived explosions. Effects removed. All in the service of a mode I'm not even playing.

There is *one* half good thing in this update. The devs have let us keep the original version of the game via a beta branch. Unfortunately that means no more updates, being locked out of the expanded late game (might have been good? I don't know, can't stomach the early game anymore so I'll never get to play it), and the further expansions. I don't have enough time to spend modding the game's visuals back to pre-nerf, removing the resource costs, restoring the economy, etc. I won't play the old version anymore since this has left such a bad taste, and I'll be lamenting missing out on potentially good new content buried deep in the botched rework of a game that was previously amazing and never needed it.

[h1]Feels like an endless tutorial[/h1]
I might have gotten the wrong impression, but I envisioned The Riftbreaker as Factorio but with an emphasis on combat and exploration. On a surface level that assumption was accurate, but in practice the two halves of the game did not mesh. 

The combat and exploration part is passable enough. Combat looks and feels great, but most of it just amounts to gunning down massive hordes of creatures. Except for a few tougher enemies, it was more about being at the right place at the right time and conserving ammo. Defending you base is a bit odd since it grows quite large and you cannot possible use turrets to defend yourself from the big hordes. Unlike Factorio, where you can predict which direction enemies are going to attack from, as well as being able to wall of big sections of the map, in The Riftbreaker enemies attack from random locations, the terrain is too open to section off and turrets are too limited to make static defenses viable. You are better off just teleporting to where enemies are attacking and shoot them yourself. Outside of attack waves, the enemies never pose any threat and do not attack your base, so it is a bit of all or nothing.

The base building was promising at first. Gather resources to build new buildings and upgrade your factory as well as forging new equipment. But it quickly plateaus and never increases in complexity. There is no logistics management and only a few multi-stage recipes. Most of your expansion is just building more and more of the same buildings.

When the game started to lose me entirely is when I realized that the game just followed the same loop over and over. Explore a new area, find new resources, unlock the next tier of stuff and return to your base. In essence it is what every survival crafting game should be about, but it was so repetitive and it felt copy pasted. Progression is also mostly linear with set objectives to complete in a set order. It kept waiting for the tutorial to be over so I could explore the game freely, but it never happened. So sense of freedom or problem solving, just follow orders.

Riftbreaker is one of those games I wish I could put like a little middling thumb on. I think it's... fine, for about half of it, and then the other half just becomes a bit of a chore. It goes from "Oh, this is novel!" to "The Keywords for today are: Repetitive, tedious."

A lot of this game is... straightforward, or simple? And I don't think that's a bad thing, it was probably the right choice for this game, I can't help that it also makes the game feel a bit mindless. There isn't really that much complexity to the building, nor the defending, nor the combat really. Sometimes it's fun to hold the mouse buttons and watch hordes of creatures turn into groups of red mists, othertimes it's really dull. There's an initial satisfaction to watching a tower-line hold a group of enemies all on its own, but then it... Now I'm repeating myself.
That is a *lot* of this game. Busy work and chores. I don't dislike it enough to give it a hard no, but I also don't like it enough to give it a hard yes.

This is only made worse when you're exploring other areas. The flow is like this:
Deploy to an area -> oh no there's something we didn't see that complicates things -> we should research a solution to this -> go to new place -> Oh there's new materials here -> hunt around for ages gathering small amounts of this resource -> get enough to scan for big deposit -> also there's some optional material (but go get it because you need new guns) -> setup two entirely new bases and then half ass them because if you aren't here you don't need to defend it.

Except it gets more irritating each time? I don't think it's bad in isolation, but these issues are rarely complex enough to have to dedicate entire... chunks of gameplay around it. The Acid area has fungus that rapidly grows all over the map. So now you get to spend ages running around the corners of the map isolating the fungus colonies with flooring that doesn't stop them from growing sometimes, or you just blow up the acid colonies because despite all of Ashley's cautioning of "This could have negative effects on the ecosystem", there apparently isn't any.

Or the lava area. You can't build anywhere that's outside of cold areas. THis is initially interesting, since you're forced to build outposts around the cold plants that naturally spring up around this zone. And also there's big magnetic rocks that stop you from building near them - I hope you went to the acid zone first to get the acid gun that destroys them, not that you'd know without constant sustained fire with a dialogue that "sort of" hints at this.
And that's skipping the part where you go here, find the complication, go to a new area to research a solution, go to a new area to get material samples, go to a new area to actually get the materials, etc.
And when you're done with all of that, you go back to HQ and build your big portal back to home and then defend it for a few minutes against huge attack waves that are a problem if you haven't prepared properly (get some long range artillery in there and a few shield generators at your frontlines), and... wait for 2 minutes because the attack waves stopped and the portal is halfway done. Huh.
That's like, basically the whole game. Do a thing, have ashley and riggs back and forth about things they both know but you're being tutorialised. Go to a new place. Dont do anything at new place but scan (thank god for scanner turrets). Go to new place. Find thing. Research thing. Unlock the solution. Build a real base at the new place. Half ass it because you're tired of defending everything. Repeat several times. Now win the game.

The game seems to just have everything in it, to the point that the games focus is sacrificed. Ostensibly, the game should be a medium-fast paced base-building w/ tower defense + exploration experience, but somehow manages to be a slow-paced twin-stick looter-shooter. It feels as if the latter cannibalized the former.

Everything feels like a massive chore.

#1 The bioscanner, it takes 3-4 seconds per scan but you'll need 30+ scans of a creature to learn what damage type it's weak to. So you are subject to this incredibly boring mechanic unless you google the information instead.

#2 The research, it takes forever, you can't just build more labs b/c there's a maximum number you are allowed to build. Research also costs a mountain of resources for some reason, meaning the typical experience is to dump the majority of your resources into *just starting the research process*, then wait around doing nothing b/c you are out of resources for the next 5 minutes. Or you might try...

#3 Exploring, there is another pod of enemies every 5 feet so just walking around looking for stuff is like trudging through deep mud, it's so obnoxious that the best upgrade for your mech is stealth. And you will want stealth for...

#4 The geoscanner, slightly more tolerable than the bioscanner, a ton of resource patches are hidden so get used to holding space-bar everywhere you go.

#5 No blueprints, practically a mortal sin for a game like this.

#6 The loot. Jesus Christ what is with the loot. You could probably finish this game without ever crafting a weapon b/c the wildlife on this unexplored alien planet are constantly dropping miniguns and rocket launchers; Mech cosmetics, different color floors & lamps, statues, weapon attachments, you name it and some space-raptor you disintegrated has it in their pocket. From what I've experienced the exploration objects ("bioanomalies") hold maybe 1 - 2 loot items and you need to explore (see above) to find them, but a typical attack wave will drop a dozen or so loot items so why even bother.

#7 Charge-Mode on weapons. The combat in this game consists of *several thousand* enemies rushing at you very fast, so why, why, why does *almost every weapon* have a charge-mode. Charge-mode (holding the button down), forces the player to split their concentration between the tsunami of space-raptors chasing them and watching/listening to the mechs right arm for the correct time to release the right mouse button; additionally charge-mode slows the mech down thus eliminating the ability to kite opponents. These are design decisions which strongly conflict. Aside from some charge-modes just being downright silly (you can charge the nuke launcher to make it nuke harder), most offer little to no advantage at all. But let us be real, you're only going to use about 10% of the arsenal anyway, none of them with charge-mode, minigun/plasmagun/laser/boxing-gloves/chainsaws.

It removes most of the challenge and most incentive to engage with all the other mechanics. Base building stops being a puzzle and just becomes a matter of manually printing a template. Your equipment dps improves by one (1) order of magnitude over the course of the game, but the majority of that is locked behind technologies that take resources from base building.

Combat is serviceable but doesn't really evolve over the course of the game. In the endgame, it starts lagging even in singleplayer, with over a second of input lag and a much reduced game speed even though Steam reports a 100fps framerate. Every weapon exists at every tech level, all the enemies that matter just become tougher reskins rather than requiring a different approach, and boss enemies are too weak to reward planning. Bioscanning adds some extra challenge but its rewards are miniscule and become logarithmically more miniscule (did you like that +5% for scanning a hundred enemies instead of shooting them? How about +10% for scanning a thousand?), and there is no complexity to it.

Exploration is fine but seems underdeveloped. There are three biomes and you only need four bases, though each of the other three bases has a short fetch quest sequence where some missions actually require creative puzzle solving. Strangely, despite the game giving you multiple different options and despite the tech tree having resource requirements that incentivize you to prioritize specific biomes depending on your basebuilding and/or weapon choice, the explanation of mechanics expects one specific order (top to bottom in the hub menu). Doing it "out of order" means hearing voice lines that refer to events that haven't happened yet and lacking information about how to use unintuitive UI elements.

The story is bare-bones, but from the amount of voice lines you wouldn't think so. They even have the characters lampshade how perfunctory their voicelines are. The characters are one-dimensional and there is no character development to speak of, and the first time the pilot's supposed care for the environment actually translates into a mechanical choice is choosing whether to go for the True Ending or not. The plot up to this point is just "do the work necessary to open a rift gate back to earth", with not even a hint of any other option until you're one keypress away from opening the gate.

Audio design is subpar. There is no volume limiter for multiple entities producing the same noise so upgrading a field of solar panels blows out your speakers. The pilot's voice actor doesn't seem to have been given good direction for her lines: her tone of voice and use of emphasis don't correlate with the gameplay and story implications of what she's saying.

The graphics design is inoffensive. Customization is perfunctory. There are at most 10 texture-only skins for your character, and a few buildings that do nothing and cost a small amount of resources.

Performance-wise, the game is poorly optimized, even within the confines of the engine. As mentioned above, endgame combat lags even on a ‚Ç¨1000 PC, but even just the bases necessary for the first ending seemed to cause a bit of lag despite only one base being visible at a time. And while mines do run out while you're not looking, enemies do not spawn, so there's no gameplay justification for rendering other bases in enough detail to cause lag. One enemy (the yeast) expands on its own and starts lagging the game if it is left unchecked for 15 minutes, despite just being a stationary field that is safe to ignore from a game mechanics perspective. There is no engine reason for this enemy to take this many resources to render, it's just less programming.

If this game was in early beta, I would say that it's brimming with potential. Tweak the game balance and performance, do a second pass on the voice lines, and it would honestly be great. But given it's four years after release, with a bunch of DLCs and with 2,0 adding more features rather than polishing the existing ones, I do not recommend this game.

OK. 

VOICE ACTING & WRITING
Honestly the less story writing there is, the better. The premise is pretty good, ultimately ruined by pro-bug activist that has bleeding heart for the local environment that would maul anyone within seconds. One thing that factory building games should avoid is making cringy voice-acting, limiting it just to prompts - Factorio does this masterfully, Satisfactory does it good as it only does per-research basis.  
This game doesn't know this and it will play dialogue at every step - not enough resources, bad placement, attack incoming, storyline blabbering and so on. The mech AI is OK and I can stomach him, however the main Mary Sue is unbearable to listen to. No, I don't care about bugs, I don't care to hear how you lost your arm for 100th time that we never see anyway. Mr Riggs rightfully calls MC insane and I wish AI would court-martial her in the field by just throwing her out of the suit and leaving to live with the bugs if her bleeding heart loves them so much.

UPDATE TWO-POINT-POO
Terrible waiting times for 'end game content' - even with max labs (which are limited), you can do ONLY THREE RESEARCHES PER HOUR, AND THERE ARE 20 NEEDED! Making long research makes sense IF there is a way to make it faster. Factorio allows you to build more research labs and supply to accelerate it as much as you wish, and Satisfactory allows you to do the same with Space Elevator progress (but just industry). More time spent does not mean its better.

To be honest, Survival is more fun than Campaign itself, especially if you do it with your friends. But if you want to commit to a campaign, play Factorio, Satisfactory or another factory builder game that respects your time and doesn't beat your head with environmentalism. Until the endgame update and the mega structures, this was great. It had many options and ways you could tackle the game. You could do the DLC in any order if you're far enough, you could progress the story regardless of your skills, and get the full experience.

There is no more balance - it is literally, "Waste all of the resources on this mega structure and kill everything that comes to destroy it."

The mega structures take colossal amounts of resources to maintain and build. That's understandable since that's literally all they're meant for. Sure, they have some good benefits, like showing the entire map and its mining spots, or increasing farm yield, but... they're thankless and full of bugs.

Get this. I built the entire thing up and powered the final structure. Mr. Riggs told me, "Hey, the last wave is coming, better be ready." I was like like, well, ok, good, bring it on. I had good defenses, I had good items and gear, so start it up. What happened next was just pathetic.

My entire base was obliterated. My mega structures, which you can build more of on one map because nothing stops you, well, one bit the dust. More than half of my base, despite finishing all of the DLC and having upgrades everywhere, was just wiped out because multiple mega units came out and just killed everything. The mods these things have are stupid - heal all in an area, prevent damage to it unless you're in its bubble, and so forth. How is a tower supposed to kill that? This isn't that kind of game!

The worst thing is you can't repair your dead mega structures, you have to just dismantle it and start from zero. I had all of them maxed. I had all of their research maxed - I literally cannot research anything else in this game and have to start over mining titanium and uranium because of these monstrosities.
The entire tone is off here, you're not solving anything and are instead killing literally all life with nukes to build stupid structures to strip-mine the planet. I can no longer maintain titanium because all of the cooling needed for these things, like what is that? The power plants alone rip apart an entire mining outpost!

Ok, so whatever. I build it back up and try again, thinking, "I have the power, I have the cooling, I have the magma and whatever else it needs. Turn it on - I died once, the final wave won't come again. That'd be dumb." The final wave comes again and just rips it all apart again. I built it all up a second time, it gets utterly annihilated again. I revert to my save and can't build my arcology again because I can't repair my dead structures.

What a cycle of hate toward the player. You make it unwinnable, you make the structures unfixable, you make the economy function on death and strip mines, and you make it endless. At that point, one of your outposts is out of resources, so you're now forced to spend hours building another to try again.

What happened here? Why do I have to fight monsters with affixes like in an ARPG with just bullet sponges and healing all over the place, not to mention invicibility zones? Why does my base mean nothing? Why is research thrown away in favor of just killing everything? Why do the resource outposts just get spat on by the requirements of endgame buildings? Are you serious with this game, because I don't get it anymore. You had something special and now have this mess where you have you spam special attacks, your towers just die all the time, you waste our lives with buildings that can't be repaired, and you're merciless in failure. Are you happy?

Putting a negative review on this game is kinda heartbreaking. For a long time this was one of the easiest recommendations I've been making to people. Hands down one of my favourite games of all time. I even did some speed running. However the coop updates have pretty much ruined the game imo. I played maybe 20 minutes into a new game once the update was out and haven't touched it since. Reading the dev log for the latest update that reworks movement skills (around mid October 2025) has been depressing, and a clear indication the game is going in a direction that I don't enjoy.

There are big issues and small issues. Some of the biggest issues have been how the economy was reworked. As the amount of bases you can have has increased, the amount of resources you can be harvesting at once has increased. To compensate, all researches now have a huge resource cost associated with them. Even the first ones you can do. You might be sitting afk for 10+mins waiting for resources because you don't get lots of resources outposts until the late game. Why this massive roadblock exists early is bizare and fun killing.
Tier 2 and 3 resource extractors now harvest half the amount. These changes mean that you need a higher amount of resource outposts simply to get to the level we had before. Why increase the amount of bases we can have when there is no benefit to it, and the huge downside of butchering the early game and wasting our time with setting up all these extra bases?

The resource cost to researches has other side effects. A lot of researches that unlock things that need rarer or later game resources also need said resource to research. This may not sound like an issue, after all if you don't have the resource you can't use the results of the research. However some items that require resources X are gated by researches that unlock items that use resource Y. Before you could research the item you can't use to get the item you can use. Now you can't. This forces a much more linear and fixed path through the game, rather than the more open choices we had before. You can turn down resource costs to 1% but not 0%, you can't get this choice back.

Previously, weapons and gear you crafted had some degree of randomness to them. The higher tier the weapon/item, the more random bonuses it would have. I can understand why some players would find making 20 of a weapon, choosing the best, and then dismantling the other 18 or 19 to be boring. Personally I found it a nice addition that let me have a little more choice in what I wanted from my gear. Do I want something super ammo efficient? Then build a weapon with better efficiency and throw on some ammo cost reduction mods. Weapons with different stats still exist, but they have to be gathered either from 'anomalies' in the environment, or as random drops from enemies. This is a pure downgrade, as we are now massively timegated in trying to aquire the gear we want. While the game does have some ARPG elements to the how combat works, it's not an ARPG and was never trying to be one. I don't want an ARPG. Stop moving the game into a new genre I beg.

The movement skill reworks have gone in this direction to. Rather than simple functional movement skills, they've all becoming flashy damaging abilities like in an ARPG. The teleport skill, one of my 2 most core movement skills, has been made visually and functionally frustrating going by the gifs they've shown off/the devs descriptions of how it works now.

Then there are the smaller issues, mainly visual. With coop being a new focus, the devs have decided to reduce a lot of visuals to make things more 'readable'. This makes the game less visually interesting and dynamic. Smaller, shorter lived explosions. Effects removed. All in the service of a mode I'm not even playing.

There is *one* half good thing in this update. The devs have let us keep the original version of the game via a beta branch. Unfortunately that means no more updates, being locked out of the expanded late game (might have been good? I don't know, can't stomach the early game anymore so I'll never get to play it), and the further expansions. I don't have enough time to spend modding the game's visuals back to pre-nerf, removing the resource costs, restoring the economy, etc. I won't play the old version anymore since this has left such a bad taste, and I'll be lamenting missing out on potentially good new content buried deep in the botched rework of a game that was previously amazing and never needed it.

[h1]Feels like an endless tutorial[/h1]
I might have gotten the wrong impression, but I envisioned The Riftbreaker as Factorio but with an emphasis on combat and exploration. On a surface level that assumption was accurate, but in practice the two halves of the game did not mesh. 

The combat and exploration part is passable enough. Combat looks and feels great, but most of it just amounts to gunning down massive hordes of creatures. Except for a few tougher enemies, it was more about being at the right place at the right time and conserving ammo. Defending you base is a bit odd since it grows quite large and you cannot possible use turrets to defend yourself from the big hordes. Unlike Factorio, where you can predict which direction enemies are going to attack from, as well as being able to wall of big sections of the map, in The Riftbreaker enemies attack from random locations, the terrain is too open to section off and turrets are too limited to make static defenses viable. You are better off just teleporting to where enemies are attacking and shoot them yourself. Outside of attack waves, the enemies never pose any threat and do not attack your base, so it is a bit of all or nothing.

The base building was promising at first. Gather resources to build new buildings and upgrade your factory as well as forging new equipment. But it quickly plateaus and never increases in complexity. There is no logistics management and only a few multi-stage recipes. Most of your expansion is just building more and more of the same buildings.

When the game started to lose me entirely is when I realized that the game just followed the same loop over and over. Explore a new area, find new resources, unlock the next tier of stuff and return to your base. In essence it is what every survival crafting game should be about, but it was so repetitive and it felt copy pasted. Progression is also mostly linear with set objectives to complete in a set order. It kept waiting for the tutorial to be over so I could explore the game freely, but it never happened. So sense of freedom or problem solving, just follow orders.

Riftbreaker is one of those games I wish I could put like a little middling thumb on. I think it's... fine, for about half of it, and then the other half just becomes a bit of a chore. It goes from "Oh, this is novel!" to "The Keywords for today are: Repetitive, tedious."

A lot of this game is... straightforward, or simple? And I don't think that's a bad thing, it was probably the right choice for this game, I can't help that it also makes the game feel a bit mindless. There isn't really that much complexity to the building, nor the defending, nor the combat really. Sometimes it's fun to hold the mouse buttons and watch hordes of creatures turn into groups of red mists, othertimes it's really dull. There's an initial satisfaction to watching a tower-line hold a group of enemies all on its own, but then it... Now I'm repeating myself.
That is a *lot* of this game. Busy work and chores. I don't dislike it enough to give it a hard no, but I also don't like it enough to give it a hard yes.

This is only made worse when you're exploring other areas. The flow is like this:
Deploy to an area -> oh no there's something we didn't see that complicates things -> we should research a solution to this -> go to new place -> Oh there's new materials here -> hunt around for ages gathering small amounts of this resource -> get enough to scan for big deposit -> also there's some optional material (but go get it because you need new guns) -> setup two entirely new bases and then half ass them because if you aren't here you don't need to defend it.

Except it gets more irritating each time? I don't think it's bad in isolation, but these issues are rarely complex enough to have to dedicate entire... chunks of gameplay around it. The Acid area has fungus that rapidly grows all over the map. So now you get to spend ages running around the corners of the map isolating the fungus colonies with flooring that doesn't stop them from growing sometimes, or you just blow up the acid colonies because despite all of Ashley's cautioning of "This could have negative effects on the ecosystem", there apparently isn't any.

Or the lava area. You can't build anywhere that's outside of cold areas. THis is initially interesting, since you're forced to build outposts around the cold plants that naturally spring up around this zone. And also there's big magnetic rocks that stop you from building near them - I hope you went to the acid zone first to get the acid gun that destroys them, not that you'd know without constant sustained fire with a dialogue that "sort of" hints at this.
And that's skipping the part where you go here, find the complication, go to a new area to research a solution, go to a new area to get material samples, go to a new area to actually get the materials, etc.
And when you're done with all of that, you go back to HQ and build your big portal back to home and then defend it for a few minutes against huge attack waves that are a problem if you haven't prepared properly (get some long range artillery in there and a few shield generators at your frontlines), and... wait for 2 minutes because the attack waves stopped and the portal is halfway done. Huh.
That's like, basically the whole game. Do a thing, have ashley and riggs back and forth about things they both know but you're being tutorialised. Go to a new place. Dont do anything at new place but scan (thank god for scanner turrets). Go to new place. Find thing. Research thing. Unlock the solution. Build a real base at the new place. Half ass it because you're tired of defending everything. Repeat several times. Now win the game.

I'll throw up my hands and admit I dragged this out longer for myself. [h1] post game spoiler discussions! [/h1]

So, the post game comes with building these megastructures. I was reassured that, yes, these buildings will be hard to construct. They cost a huge amount of resources, require a lot of logistics, and I need to plan around them!

 But it was beaten like all the rest. In the old, faithful combat style of industrialisation...
MANIFOLD STYLE.

This isn't even going into the story, which is... like it's there. Ostensibly, the game should be a medium-fast paced base-building w/ tower defense + exploration experience, but somehow manages to be a slow-paced twin-stick looter-shooter. It feels as if the latter cannibalized the former.

Everything feels like a massive chore.

#1 The bioscanner, it takes 3-4 seconds per scan but you'll need 30+ scans of a creature to learn what damage type it's weak to. So you are subject to this incredibly boring mechanic unless you google the information instead.

#2 The research, it takes forever, you can't just build more labs b/c there's a maximum number you are allowed to build. Research also costs a mountain of resources for some reason, meaning the typical experience is to dump the majority of your resources into *just starting the research process*, then wait around doing nothing b/c you are out of resources for the next 5 minutes. Or you might try...

#3 Exploring, there is another pod of enemies every 5 feet so just walking around looking for stuff is like trudging through deep mud, it's so obnoxious that the best upgrade for your mech is stealth. And you will want stealth for...

#4 The geoscanner, slightly more tolerable than the bioscanner, a ton of resource patches are hidden so get used to holding space-bar everywhere you go.

#5 No blueprints, practically a mortal sin for a game like this.

#6 The loot. Jesus Christ what is with the loot. You could probably finish this game without ever crafting a weapon b/c the wildlife on this unexplored alien planet are constantly dropping miniguns and rocket launchers; Mech cosmetics, different color floors & lamps, statues, weapon attachments, you name it and some space-raptor you disintegrated has it in their pocket. From what I've experienced the exploration objects ("bioanomalies") hold maybe 1 - 2 loot items and you need to explore (see above) to find them, but a typical attack wave will drop a dozen or so loot items so why even bother.

#7 Charge-Mode on weapons. The combat in this game consists of *several thousand* enemies rushing at you very fast, so why, why, why does *almost every weapon* have a charge-mode. Charge-mode (holding the button down), forces the player to split their concentration between the tsunami of space-raptors chasing them and watching/listening to the mechs right arm for the correct time to release the right mouse button; additionally charge-mode slows the mech down thus eliminating the ability to kite opponents. These are design decisions which strongly conflict. Aside from some charge-modes just being downright silly (you can charge the nuke launcher to make it nuke harder), most offer little to no advantage at all. But let us be real, you're only going to use about 10% of the arsenal anyway, none of them with charge-mode, minigun/plasmagun/laser/boxing-gloves/chainsaws.

Very clunky and unpolished. Even in "version 2.0", four years after its original release, it feels like an early beta. The elevator pitch for the game is that it wants to synergize several different genres by feeding rewards from doing well in one area into doing well in other areas. It's a neat idea, and it's executed well enough that I did play one whole campaign, but the execution is so messy that I would not recommend it for single player and probably not for multiplayer.

For me, the nail in the coffin of this recommendation is that the balance between different game aspects is bad. There is one right way to play in terms of power scaling and it makes all the other ways minor fiddly obstacles. In single player this is annoying, and I imagine that in multiplayer it would just be sad that the people who focus on different aspects see far less award for their efforts.

There is a very simple exponential loop in base building resource generation that shows up a few hours in and stays for the rest of the game. It removes most of the challenge and most incentive to engage with all the other mechanics. Base building stops being a puzzle and just becomes a matter of manually printing a template. Enemies die to "just use more gun". Even narratively this option is the "green" one. Tech is cheap compared to the power potential of base building.

Equipment handling is a nightmare. Maybe that's subjective, but the reward for doing it well is objectively pitiful. While base building gives you orders of magnitude improvement, equipment bonuses are less than +50% even at the highest level of equipment slot. Your equipment dps improves by one (1) order of magnitude over the course of the game, but the majority of that is locked behind technologies that take resources from base building.

Combat is serviceable but doesn't really evolve over the course of the game. In the endgame, it starts lagging even in singleplayer, with over a second of input lag and a much reduced game speed even though Steam reports a 100fps framerate. Every weapon exists at every tech level, all the enemies that matter just become tougher reskins rather than requiring a different approach, and boss enemies are too weak to reward planning. Bioscanning adds some extra challenge but its rewards are miniscule and become logarithmically more miniscule (did you like that +5% for scanning a hundred enemies instead of shooting them? How about +10% for scanning a thousand?), and there is no complexity to it.

Exploration is fine but seems underdeveloped. There are three biomes and you only need four bases, though each of the other three bases has a short fetch quest sequence where some missions actually require creative puzzle solving. Strangely, despite the game giving you multiple different options and despite the tech tree having resource requirements that incentivize you to prioritize specific biomes depending on your basebuilding and/or weapon choice, the explanation of mechanics expects one specific order (top to bottom in the hub menu). Doing it "out of order" means hearing voice lines that refer to events that haven't happened yet and lacking information about how to use unintuitive UI elements.

The story is bare-bones, but from the amount of voice lines you wouldn't think so. They even have the characters lampshade how perfunctory their voicelines are. The characters are one-dimensional and there is no character development to speak of, and the first time the pilot's supposed care for the environment actually translates into a mechanical choice is choosing whether to go for the True Ending or not. The plot up to this point is just "do the work necessary to open a rift gate back to earth", with not even a hint of any other option until you're one keypress away from opening the gate.

Audio design is subpar. There is no volume limiter for multiple entities producing the same noise so upgrading a field of solar panels blows out your speakers. The pilot's voice actor doesn't seem to have been given good direction for her lines: her tone of voice and use of emphasis don't correlate with the gameplay and story implications of what she's saying.

The graphics design is inoffensive. Customization is perfunctory. There are at most 10 texture-only skins for your character, and a few buildings that do nothing and cost a small amount of resources.

Performance-wise, the game is poorly optimized, even within the confines of the engine. As mentioned above, endgame combat lags even on a ‚Ç¨1000 PC, but even just the bases necessary for the first ending seemed to cause a bit of lag despite only one base being visible at a time. And while mines do run out while you're not looking, enemies do not spawn, so there's no gameplay justification for rendering other bases in enough detail to cause lag. One enemy (the yeast) expands on its own and starts lagging the game if it is left unchecked for 15 minutes, despite just being a stationary field that is safe to ignore from a game mechanics perspective. There is no engine reason for this enemy to take this many resources to render, it's just less programming.

If this game was in early beta, I would say that it's brimming with potential. Tweak the game balance and performance, do a second pass on the voice lines, and it would honestly be great. But given it's four years after release, with a bunch of DLCs and with 2,0 adding more features rather than polishing the existing ones, I do not recommend this game.
